sections.1_story: Imagine you have two types of milk with different fat percentages and you want to mix them to get a desired quality. Mixtures and Alligation help you calculate the right proportions.
2_definitions: ğŸ’¡ Mixture: A combination of two or more substances.
ğŸ’¡ Alligation: A rule to find the ratio in which two or more ingredients at given prices must be mixed to produce a mixture at a given price.
ğŸ’¡ Mean Price: The price of a unit quantity of the mixture.
ğŸ’¡ Cheaper Quantity: The quantity of the ingredient with a lower value.
ğŸ’¡ Dearer Quantity: The quantity of the ingredient with a higher value.
ğŸ’¡ Replacement: Removing a part of the mixture and replacing it with another substance.
ğŸ’¡ Concentration: The amount of a substance in a mixture.
ğŸ’¡ Ratio: The relation between quantities.
ğŸ’¡ Proportion: An equation stating two ratios are equal.
ğŸ’¡ Alligation Rule: (C-D):(D-M) = Ratio of quantities (C = costlier, D = mean, M = cheaper).
